Stem: Lake Erie has been negatively affected by algal blooms during periods of warmer weather. These blooms consist of excessive growth of cyanobacteria (blue-green algae phytoplankton), which are capable of producing toxins that pose a risk to human and animal health. The overgrowth of this algae creates thick mats on the lake’s surface (algal bloom) that block sunlight from reaching underwater plants. The photo below shows an algal bloom occurring. Which argument correctly describes how an algal bloom could affect populations of organisms in Lake Erie?
Choices: A) Some photosynthetic organisms would not receive enough energy in order to make food., B) The population of mussels would be unaffected because they would feed on zooplankton instead of algae., C) Toxins would cause the population of smallmouth bass to increase because the population of emerald shiner would increase., D) Bottom feeders, like the round goby, would live closer to the surface of the lake in order to feed on phytoplankton. House sparrows eat mostly grains and seeds, but, in summer, will eat insects and feed them to their young. Which option BEST identifies the interaction between a house sparrow and a bluebird in the same habitat and gives environmental factors that lead to this interaction?
Choices: A) Competition; limited nesting options and overlapping food sources., B) Mutualism; both birds share nests and warn each other about predators., C) Parasitism; sparrows feed on bluebird blood and the scarcity of water forces this behavior., D) Commensalism; sparrows use bluebird nests but bluebirds are unaffected because food is abundant. Stem: What piece of evidence from the entries in the student’s journal BEST supports the conclusion made on day 35?
Choices: A) During the first 15 days, the plants all looked the same. B, C) The five seeds given plant food were all at least 5 cm taller than the group without plant food., D) There was no difference between the plant food group and the other group without plant food.
Scenario Justification: Minimal or no scenario. Question is straightforward recall or identification.
SEP Justification: Requires constructing explanations or engaging in argumentation.
DCI Justification: Some content engagement in answer choices but limited reasoning with DCI.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement. No patterns, cause/effect, or systems thinking required.
Key Recommendation: Add a real-world phenomenon or puzzling scenario that students need to figure out. Push beyond recall — require students to reason with science ideas, not just identify them.
